div.p: itu tōḻi talaimakaḷatu kuṟippaṟintu vāyilākap pukka pāṇaṉ kēṭpak kuyavaṉaik kūvi “yiṅṅaṉañ collāyō” eṉṟu kuyavaṟkuc colliyatu.
This is how the confidante said to the potter “are you talking like this?”, calling the potter so that the bard could hear who had entered as a mediator knowing the intentions of HER.

lg.l: O potter of old wisdom who talks about [the coming] festival
in the streets wide [and] long like a river gone to rest,
wearing the garland of Nocci with bright ears

resembling ears of grain tied in a chaplet(?)kaṇṇikaṭṭiya: the TL takes this as a lexeme meaning "to bud", and so does T.V.G., only that he reads it to be referring to the unripe state of the grains.,
shouldn't you tellIt is the particle mātō which marks the question as rhetorical and ironic in intent and is as thus best rendered by an English negative question. there also this,
as you go to the village with [its] pond
in the sweet big paddy fields, thickly grown with white waterlilies?
o you women with sharp teeth [and] beautifully broad hips,
beware of his cruel words, a hoard of lies,

that are increasing the unhappiness [already] caused.”The last four lines seem to be anacoluthic, or at least I for one do not see a way of construing them convincingly, but for once the sense is clear, nevertheless.
